results.title: The City and the future
results.creator_credit: Guy Glover, Ian MacNeill and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Lewis Mumford on the city”.
Today an urgent choice must be made - an urban sprawl or a new kind of regional city. Examines prospects for the city and ways to restore its role as the focus of man’s highest achievement

results.title: The City and it's regions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Lewis Mumford on the city”.
History shows that cities thrive best when they live in harmony and balance with the countryside around them. The film asks how this balance can be maintained or restored in today’s sprawling metropolitan regions.

results.title: The City's edge
results.creator_credit: New South Wales Film Corporation, CB Films (France), Oliver Sullivan Productions, Pom Oliver, Errol Sullivan and Ken Quinnell
results.brief_description: A dramatic contemporary love story of an aspiring young writer from the country and an urban woman struggling against the guilt of her first sexual experiences. They become involved with each other, their pasts and a frightening narrow world that is dominated by a charismatic young Aborigine who is driven by a contempt for life and a fierce hatred of white Australian society. Starring Hugo Weaving, Tommy Lewis, Shirley Cameron and Mark Lee. Co-starring Ralph Cotterill, Julie McGregor, Frederic Abbott, Martin Harris and Katrina Foster. Based on the novel by W. A. Harbinson.

results.title: The City
results.creator_credit: American Documentary Films, Falph Steiner and Willard Van Dyke
results.brief_description: An indictment of unplanned city growth and uncontrolled expansion of industry, this is one of America’s best documentary films, famous for its “eating sequence”. The film has three distinct sections: first, the early pastoral life of the American colonies; the chaotic and industrialised metropolis, the sprawling contrasting city, the dirt, poverty, ill health and despair of the victims of the industrial city’s haphazard growth; the necessity for planned city growth. Based on Lewis Mumford’s book, “The Culture of Cities”, this film owes much of its punch to the editing of well-chosen details, excellently photographed, enabling the film to argue visually.

results.title: The Citizen rebels = Il cittadino si ribella
results.brief_description: Carlo, a self-employed industrial engineer is held at gunpoint by a gang of hoodlums while he is queueing at the local post office. In a struggle to conceal his money from the thugs he is beaten senseless, abducted, and left for dead in their abandoned getaway vehicle. When the local police fail to act on his behalf, Carlo decides to take the matter into his own hands, firstly through his lawyer (who is helpless to assist him), then by his own less legitimate devices. Cast includes Franco Nero and Barbara Bach. In Italian with no English subtitles.

results.title: The Circle = Dayereh = Il Cerchio [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi Film Productions, Mikado Film Srl (Rome), Lumière & Co. and Jafar Panahi
results.brief_description: From Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi (The White balloon), comes “The Circle” a tale of female oppression in modern day Iran. “The Circle” opens in a hospital maternity ward where a woman has just given birth. Her mother is horrified by the catastrophic outcome - its a girl. She had been assured (via ultrasound) that it would be a boy and laments the fact that a divorce will ensue and her daughter will be shamed. This opening sequence reflects the status of women in Iran, as unwanted, second-class citizens without rights or a voice in society. “The Circle” tells the stories of several women in a city over the course of one day and night. Simple acts of buying a bus ticket or smoking a cigarette in public are denied to women and are punishable by law. The women of the film, in constant danger of imprisonment and harassment, are shunned by their families and seek refuge with each other. Panahi adopts a documentary style for this feature film, as street noise fills the soundtrack and the camera follows the characters around, almost hounding them. “The Circle” was banned in Iran due to its controversial subject matter. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Golden Lion, Best Film at the 2000 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: The Circle
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, John Kemeny and Mort Ransen
results.brief_description: Produced in 1967, this black and white film is an inmate’s view of Daytop, a drug treatment center on Staten Island, New York, where addicts learn to get along without drugs. Uncompromising, often brutal group therapy sessions are designed to shake loose the excuses a victim makes for himself. The people and situations shown are authentic; only one actor was employed. The results obtained at Daytop are regarded by some psychiatrists as a breakthrough. Cast: Don Francks.
